all array based binder-free cathode for high performance lithium–sulfur batteries†
Junling Guo, Xiaolong Zhang, Xinyu Du and Fengxiang Zhang*
Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have recently attracted great interest owing to their high theoretical energy density (2500 kW kg 1) and low cost and the environmental friendliness of sulfur as the active species at the
cathode. However, rapid capacity fading restricts practical application of LSBs. Despite the encouraging
progress achieved, this issue still needs to be further addressed. Herein, we report a novel cathode
structure based on nano-wall-array Mn3O4 which shows excellent cycle and rate performances. In such a cathode, the Mn3O4 nano-wall arrays function as “nano reservoirs” for sulfur confinement so that the cathode can yield a high-rate (2C) initial ( 593 mA h g 1) and reversible capacity ( 355 mA h g 1, 60% retention after 3000 cycles). We also show, by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic and electrochemical
analyses, that Mn3O4 as a sulfur-hosting oxide is better than conventionally used MnO2; this is because the former shows better chemical stability in the electrolyte when binding with polysulfides, giving rise to
long-lasting suppression of polysulfide shuttle. Our work demonstrates that building a nano-wall array
structure of Mn3O4 is an effective strategy to improve lithium–sulfur cathode performance, and for the first time, we propose and show that the stability of polar materials in the electrolyte is a crucial factor
that determines the cycle performance of polar materials/S electrodes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As a promising candidate for next-generation energy storage technology, lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have been widely studied because of their prominent advantages over other batteries, including a very high theoretical energy density (2500 kW kg 1), low cost and non-toxicity of sulfur.1–6 Despite these advantages, practical applications of LSBs are currently hindered by several obstacles: (1) the sulfur cathodes experience a signicant volume change (up to 80%) during discharging which leads to an irreversible deterioration of the cathode structure;7–10 (2) the dissolution of the cathode reaction intermediates (lithium polysuldes) in the organic electrolyte during the charge/discharge process creates an adverse “shuttle effect”, leading to poor cycle performance and low coulombic efficiency;11–13 (3) poor conductivity of sulfur and lithium suldes results in low utilization of sulfur and low rate capability.14–16
Many research efforts have been made to solve the aforementioned problems. These efforts mostly concentrate on the development of advanced sulfur cathode structures,17,18 new electrolytes19 and novel separators.20 For advanced cathode

structuring, carbon materials have been most frequently employed as the sulfur immobilizer because their high conductivity reduces polarization of the cathode and their high specic surface area helps to trap the redox intermediates by physical interaction.21 Such carbon materials include mesoporous carbon,12–24 hollow porous carbon spheres,25–27 carbon nanotubes,28,29 graphene,30 conductive polymer nanotubes31 and so on; cathodes based on these materials can yield high specic capacity, but the capacity oen decays seriously during prolonged cycling because the carbon materials are non-polar in nature and unable to bind strongly to polar polysuldes. The binding ability of carbon materials toward polysuldes can be improved by nitrogen-doping,32 hierarchical structure construction, and so on,33 but the complexity involved in the design and manufacturing process reduces the feasibility.34
Another promising approach toward better cycle performance of Li–S batteries is to utilize the chemical interactions between polar materials and the lithium polysulde (LiPS) species.35 A series of polar materials such as TiO2,36 Ti4O7,37 MnO2,38,39 SiO2,40 Al2O3,41,42 La2O3 43 andMg0.6Ni0.4O44 have been employed for sulfur hosting, and the resultant Li–S batteries exhibited signicantly better cycle performances than those basedmerely on carbonmaterials. Nonetheless, the much lower electron and ionic conductivities (compared with carbon materials) of these polar materials inevitably impede electron and lithium ion transport, thus leading to lower sulfur utilization and rate capability. Therefore, it is still a great challenge to

Herein, we report nano-wall array Mn3O4 directly grown on carbon cloth as the cathode of Li–S batteries. This is a binderfree cathode with the following advantages: (1) Mn3O4, as a sulfur hosting material, is better than MnO2 because Mn3O4 shows better stability in the electrolyte aer binding with polysuldes; (2) the Mn3O4 nano-wall array structure forms numerous “nano-reservoirs”, and thus can conne polysuldes and minimize the shuttle effect effectively; (3) rapid electron and lithium-ion transport is ensured by the nano-wall array 3D framework, which can enhance sulfur utilization and rate capability; (4) the “nano-reservoirs” formed with the nano-walls provide enough space to accommodate the signicant volume change of sulfur during discharging. Our designed cathode also makes full use of the general merits of nano-structured array electrodes in energy storage, such as sufficient contact of active materials with the electrolyte, facile electron collection and so on.45 As a result, a high sulfur utilization (1208 mA h g 1 at 0.1C), superior rate performance (955, 755, 583 and 179 mA h g 1 at 0.5, 1, 2, and 4C, respectively) and ultra-long cycle life (60% capacity retention aer 3000 cycles at 2C, or 0.013% capacity decay per cycle) can be realized in the “reservoir-like” Mn3O4 nano-wall array architecture.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials preparation
sections.text:
2.1.1 Mn3O4 nano-wall arrays on carbon cloth. A piece of carbon cloth and a solution containing 40 mL deionized water, 0.13 mL hydrochloric acid (37%), and 0.45 g potassium permanganate were added into an 80 mL Teon-lined stainless steel reactor. This reactor was sealed and maintained at 200 C for 30 min so that a hydrothermal reaction took place inside. Aer the reaction, the carbon cloth was taken out of the reactor, washed with ethanol, dried in air and nally calcined at 400 C for 2 h in argon gas.
2.1.2 MnO2 nano-wall arrays on carbon cloth. A solution containing 40 mL deionized water and 0.45 g of KMnO4, together with a piece of carbon cloth, was added into a Teonlined stainless steel reactor (80 mL). The reactor was transferred into an oven and maintained at 80 C for 12 h, aer which the carbon cloth was taken out, washed with DI water and dried in air at 60 C.
2.1.3 Mn3O4/MnO2 nano-wall array/S electrode. A modied literature method was adopted.36 1% sulfur solution in toluene was dropped onto the carbon cloth covered with Mn3O4/MnO2 nano-wall arrays and then dried on a hot plate for 20 min. The sample wasmaintained for 12 h at 155 C in an argon lled oven at a reduced pressure before it was washed with methanol for 30 s. Samples with different contents of sulfur were prepared by dropping different dosages of 1% toluene solution of sulfur onto the Mn3O4 nano-wall array covered carbon cloth.
2.1.4 Mn3O4 nano-wall powder. The Mn3O4 nano-wall array covered carbon cloth was calcined at 700 C for 2 h in air to burn off the carbon cloth, and then Mn3O4 nano-wall powder was collected.
6448 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2017, 5, 6447–6454
2.1.5 Mn3O4 nano-wall powder/S composite. A modied literature method was adopted.36 0.5 mg of Mn3O4 nano-wall powder (on an aluminum foil) was loaded into a small quartz tube, together with 50 mL of 1% sulfur solution in toluene. The mixture was then dried on a hot plate for 20 min. The sample was maintained for 12 h at 155 C in an argon lled oven at a reduced pressure before it was washed with methanol for 30 s.
2.1.6 Mn3O4 nano-wall powder/S electrode (supported on Cu foil). The Mn3O4 nano-wall powder and poly(vinylidene uoride) binder were mixed homogeneously in a weight ratio of 85 : 15 and dissolved in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. The formed slurry was then uniformly coated on a copper foil current collector to form a 300 mm thick active layer and dried under vacuum at 110 C for 10 h.

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials characterization
sections.text: Scanning electron microscope (SEM) characterization was carried out by using an FEI NanoSEM-450 Nova scanning electron microscope with a eld emission gun (FEG) source. Transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI TecnaiG2 F30) characterization was used to further understand the distribution of sulfur. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Shimadzu, XRD-7000S) with Cu Ka radiation (l ¼ 1.5416 Å) was used to probe the composition and phase of the electrodes. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was implemented with an ESCALAB™ 250Xi ThermoFisher X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Before being quickly transferred to the chamber of an ultra-high vacuum XPS system for analysis, the samples were sealed in a vial lled with N2. The sulfur content of the material was characterized using TGA (SDT, Q600) employing a heating rate of 10 C min 1 from room temperature to 850 C in air.

sections.heading: 2.3. Battery assembly and measurements
sections.text: Batteries were assembled in an argon-lled glovebox. The Mn3O4 nano-wall powder electrode and the Mn3O4 nano-wall array electrode were used as the cathode, respectively, and a Li-metal circular foil (0.59 mm thick) was used as both counter and reference electrodes. The two electrodes were separated with a polypropylene (PP) membrane. 1 M lithium bis(triuoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) in a mixture of 1,3- dioxolane (DOL) and dimethoxymethane (DME) (1 : 1, v/v) with 0.2 M LiNO3 was used as the electrolyte. All cells were aged for 8 h before measurement. Discharge–charge testing was performed at 20 C by using a multichannel battery tester (Shenzhen Neware Technology Co., Ltd, China).

sections.heading: 3.2. Optimization of sulfur loading
sections.text:
To optimize sulfur loading on the Mn3O4 nano-wall array covered carbon cloth, we prepared cathodes of different sulfur contents (1.3, 2.8 and 5.5 mg cm 2). The SEM images in Fig. S2† suggest that the voids between Mn3O4 nano-walls gradually decrease with increasing sulfur loading. When the sulfur loading reached the highest (5.5 mg cm 2), the voids were almost lled with sulfur, which may remarkably reduce the rate performance and the volume change accommodating ability.
The mass-based specic capacities and rate performances of cathodes with varied sulfur loadings are displayed in Fig. 2a. Note that the carbon cloth has no contribution to the capacity within the potential range of 1.5–3 V vs. Li/Li+ (Fig. S3†). It is apparent from Fig. 2a that the 1.3 mg cm 2 electrode exhibits the highest specic capacity and the best rate performance. This is good, but a more reasonable sulfur loading should be determined by further considering the area capacities of the electrodes.52,53 The area-based specic capacity and rate performance are given in Fig. 2b, where the 5.5 mg cm 2 electrode, although high in sulfur loading, shows a lower area

The cycle performance of these electrodes at 0.5C is displayed in Fig. 2c. Although they show virtually the same coulombic efficiencies (ca. 98% aer the rst few cycles), the capacity of the 5.5 mg cm 2 electrode decayed more rapidly in the rst ten cycles than that of the 1.3 and 2.8 mg cm 2 electrodes; this implies that the Mn3O4 nanosheet array structure has an optimal sulfur hosting capacity of 3 mg cm 2, which is determined by its specic surface area (254 m2 g 1, shown in Fig. S4†). Comparing Fig. 2a and b, one can nd that the 2.8 mg cm 2 electrode shows better balanced mass and areal rate performance (see Table S1†), and therefore it was chosen as the sample for further study.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical performance of the Mn3O4 nano-wall array cathode with optimized sulfur loading
sections.text:
The electrochemical performance of the 2.8 mg cm 2 electrode was further evaluated. In this electrode, the sulfur content is 61.76 wt% based on the Mn3O4 nano-wall/S composite and 19.43 wt% when the current collector was taken into account (Fig. S5a†). The sulfur content of the whole electrode is superior or comparable to those of some reported state-of-the-art electrodes (Table S2† for details).54–58 Its rst charge–discharge curves at 0.1 to 4C are displayed in Fig. 3a. The discharge curves

Fig. 3b depicts the rate performance of the electrode: its capacity reaches 1208 mA h g 1 at 0.1C, indicating good utilization of sulfur; the capacity changes to 955, 755, 583 and 179 mA h g 1 at 0.5, 1, 2 and 4C, respectively. This superior rate capability reveals good kinetics of the electrode, which is attributable to the Mn3O4 nano-wall array structure and optimized sulfur loading. The electrode also exhibits an ultra-long cycle life (Fig. 3c), with 60% of its initial capacity retained aer 3000 cycles at 2C (0.013% capacity decay per cycle). The cycled electrode had a sulfur content of 11.31 wt% (relative to the whole electrode mass, Fig. S5a†), equivalent to 57.85% of the initial sulfur content; this sulfur retention is obtained from Mc/Cc1 Cs2/Ms1, where Mc and Ms1 are the mass of carbon cloth ( 10 mg cm 2) and S (2.8 mg cm 2), respectively, in the initial electrode, and Cc1 and Cs2 are the content of carbon cloth in the initial electrode (68.54%) and the content of S in the cycled electrode (11.31%), respectively; this reects the good cycle stability of the electrode, and is better than some of the state-of-the-art Mn–O/S electrodes12,38,39 as detailed in Table S3.†

sections.heading: 3.4. Analysis of the performance of the Mn3O4 nano-wall array/sulfur cathode

To further understand the good performance of the Mn3O4 nanowall array electrode, we made a comparison between the array and powder electrodes of the Mn3O4 nano-wall (the powder was obtained by burning off the carbon cloth from the array electrode). To guarantee the comparability of these two electrodes, the sulfur content of theMn3O4 powder/S composite andMn3O4 powder/S @ Al foil electrode was controlled at 61.14 and 19.98 wt%, respectively (based on TGA results, Fig. S5b†), which are close to those of the Mn3O4 nano-wall/S composite (61.76 wt%) and Mn3O4 nano-wall/S @ carbon cloth array electrode (19.43

As seen from the rst charge–discharge curves (Fig. 4a), the nano-array electrode exhibits small potential polarization and high capacity relative to the powder electrode, indicating better kinetics of the former due to the unique nano-wall array architecture.59 This is further indicated by the poor rate performance of the powder electrode (Fig. 4b), which delivers a charge capacity of 1051 mA h g 1 at 0.1C and the capacity decreased to 479, 190, 40 and 15 mA h g 1 at 0.5, 1, 2 and 4C, respectively, which are much lower than the capacity of the array electrode at each current density. Based on the above comparison, the nano-wall structure is the crucial reason for the high rate performance of the electrode. This is attributed to the merits of the “reservoir-like” nano-wall array structure, including rapid electron and lithium-ion transport, sufficient contact of the active materials with the electrolyte, and facile electron collection (illustrated in Scheme 2a).
As Scheme 2a shows, the array electrode is binder-free and the Mn3O4 nanosheet is grown directly on the surface of the carbon cloth; therefore, electrons can ow from the carbon cloth to the Mn3O4 nanosheet and reach a reaction site for the electrochemical reaction without the need to pass through sulfur. In the powder electrode, however, electrons have to pass through Mn3O4, sulfur and the binder before reaching a reaction point (Scheme 2c); both sulfur and the binder (PVDF) are non-conductive, thus leading to higher polarization of the powder electrode. This can be seen from the smaller chargetransfer resistance (Rct) of the nanosheet array electrode than that of the powder electrode (Fig. S6†). Another piece of evidence comes from the difference in their aging time (before regular discharge): the nano-array electrode needs 1 h and the powder electrode needs 8 h, suggesting that the active materials can be in sufficient contact with the electrolyte in the nano-array electrode.

3.4.2 The role of Mn3O4 for sulfur hosting. Since the cycle performances revealed in Fig. 5a and b are not strikingly different, it is believed that the nano-wall structure may not be the sole factor to determine the cycle performance and the Mn3O4 material itself may also play a key role. To ascertain this reasoning, we next compared theMn3O4/S electrode withMnO2/ S, both featuring the nano-wall array structure. The MnO2 nanowall array was prepared by a modied hydrothermal process,38 which produced uniformly distributed MnO2 nano-wall arrays on the carbon bers (Fig. 6a–c). Their morphology aer cycling is given in Fig. 7b–g, where the Mn3O4 electrode shows a virtually intact nano-wall structure aer 3000 cycles, while the MnO2 nano-wall structure collapsed aer 1500 cycles of operation. The above observations suggest better stability of Mn3O4 than MnO2 in the electrolyte aer binding with polysuldes. Such a high stability constitutes a crucial reason for the highly stable cycle performance of the Mn3O4 based cathode compared with that based on MnO2.
The different stabilities of Mn3O4 and MnO2 may arise from their different reactions with Li2Sn (4 < n < 8). The structure of MnO2 is displayed in Fig. 8a, where manganese oxide containing predominantly Mn4+ cations is assembled into layers of octahedra. According to Nazar et al.,38 MnO2 hosts sulfur by its reaction with Li2Sn (4 < n < 8), causing the reduction of Mn
4+ to Mn2+. However, the resulting Mn2+ ions can be dissolved readily into the electrolyte during the charge–discharge process,63–65 which will destroy the structure of MnO2 and then weaken its ability to entrap polysuldes (Fig. 8b). MnO2 dissolution in the electrolyte can be indicated directly by an XPS study of the following polypropylene separator samples: sample 1 simply underwent a 3 h immersion in the fresh electrolyte, sample 2 is from the MnO2 nano-sheet array@CC/S cell that has completed 10 discharge–charge cycles at 0.1C, and sample 3 is from the Mn3O4 nano-sheet array@CC/S cell cycled 10 times at 0.1C. As shown in Fig. S7,† sample 2 exhibits a clear XPS peak at 630– 660 eV attributed to Mn 2p while the other two samples do not, meaning that some MnO2 was dissolved into the electrolyte when interacting with the polysulde species.
The structure of Mn3O4 is displayed in Fig. 8c, where Mn 4+ occupies the 8a sites and is distributed at the surface; Mn2+ occupies the interior 16d sites and O2+ lls in the 32e sites.

Our proposed conversion mode of Mn3O4 when exposed to polysuldes can be corroborated with XPS analysis. Fig. 9a displays the XPS Mn 2p3/2 spectrum of Mn3O4. Curve tting gives two strong peak components at 640.4 and 642.5 eV, attributable to Mn2+ and Mn4+, respectively; a weak peak arises at 641.4 eV (attributable to Mn3+), which may be caused by the reduction of surface Mn4+ during Mn3O4 synthesis.69–71 The peak component ratio is in agreement with the theoretical value (Mn3O4 can be described as [Mn
4+][Mn2+]2[O]4). When the electrode was discharged to 2 V, XPS (Fig. 9b) shows an increased peak component of Mn3+ and decreased components of Mn4+ and Mn2+. This strongly corroborates our conjecture about the conversion mode of Mn3O4 when exposed to polysuldes. In this conversion, there is no Mn2+ existence at the outside surface upon Mn3O4 interaction with polysuldes. Therefore, Mn3O4 is more stable than MnO2 as a sulfur hosting material. The above XPS results, coupled with SEM observations shown in Fig. 7, conrm that Mn3O4 is more stable than MnO2 when entrapping polysuldes.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, we have successfully fabricated a “reservoir-like” nano-wall Mn3O4 array and demonstrated its application as a cathode for Li–S batteries. This cathode could deliver a superior rate performance (1208, 955, 755, 583 and 179 mA h g 1 at 0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, and 4C, respectively) and excellent cycle performance (60% capacity retention aer 3000 cycles at 2C, or 0.013% capacity decay per cycle). Our investigations show that the “reservoir-like” nano-wall array structure is the main reason for the high rate performance of the cathode. We also compared Mn3O4 and MnO2 as sulfur hosting materials to entrap polar polysuldes based on XPS and SEM analyses, and nd that Mn3O4 is more stable than MnO2 in the electrolyte when they bind polysuldes; this is a crucial factor that determines the cycle performance of polar materials/S composite electrodes. For the rst time our work suggests and conrms that the stability of polar materials in the electrolyte aer binding to polysuldes should be adequately considered when selecting or designing polar materials for high performance sulfur cathodes.

metadata.abstractText: Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have recently attracted great interest owing to their high theoretical energy density (2500 kW kg ) and low cost and the environmental friendliness of sulfur as the active species at the cathode. However, rapid capacity fading restricts practical application of LSBs. Despite the encouraging progress achieved, this issue still needs to be further addressed. Herein, we report a novel cathode structure based on nano-wall-array Mn3O4 which shows excellent cycle and rate performances. In such a cathode, the Mn3O4 nano-wall arrays function as “nano reservoirs” for sulfur confinement so that the cathode can yield a high-rate (2C) initial ( 593 mA h g ) and reversible capacity ( 355 mA h g , 60% retention after 3000 cycles). We also show, by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic and electrochemical analyses, that Mn3O4 as a sulfur-hosting oxide is better than conventionally used MnO2; this is because the former shows better chemical stability in the electrolyte when binding with polysulfides, giving rise to long-lasting suppression of polysulfide shuttle. Our work demonstrates that building a nano-wall array structure of Mn3O4 is an effective strategy to improve lithium–sulfur cathode performance, and for the first time, we propose and show that the stability of polar materials in the electrolyte is a crucial factor that determines the cycle performance of polar materials/S electrodes.
